page.title: 16ST WULSTANS HOSPITAL MALVERN
page.content: The 65 single storey buildings covering 88 acres were an army camp. In 1950 they became a{National Health {Service hospital}for tuberculosis. In 1961 they changed to treating{mental {illness}for which St Wulstan's became nationally famous. With 93 in-patients 45 out-patients and 150 staff it is running at about half capacity because it is gradually{closing down.}The site is peaceful but remote, the buildings are{deteriorating}and it is considered desirable for patients to be in hostels in the{community}rather than in one specialised unit. Many patients have been there since 1961. Most can leave if they wish unless they might endanger their own lives or someone else. To encourage a{normal working {life}they are paid for working in the gardens, offices, kitchens, laundry or workshops making plastic bags, fences.
